content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number. Figures 1 and 2, shown, illustrate regions in the first quadrant associated with the graphs of <math alttext="y equals the fraction 1 over x, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="y equals the fraction 1 over x squared, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mfrac></math>, respectively. In Figure 1, let <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the region bounded by the graph of <math alttext="y equals the fraction 1 over x, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>, the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis, and the vertical lines <math alttext="x equals 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="x equals 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. In Figure 2, let <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>W</mi></math> be the unbounded region between the graph of <math alttext="y equals the fraction 1 over x squared, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mfrac></math> and the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-axis that lies to the right of the vertical line <math alttext="x equals 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. (a) Find the area of region <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number. Figures 1 and 2, shown, illustrate regions in the first quadrant associated with the graphs of <math alttext="y equals the fraction 1 over x, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="y equals the fraction 1 over x squared, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mfrac></math>, respectively. In Figure 1, let <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the region bounded by the graph of <math alttext="y equals the fraction 1 over x, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>, the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis, and the vertical lines <math alttext="x equals 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="x equals 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. In Figure 2, let <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>W</mi></math> be the unbounded region between the graph of <math alttext="y equals the fraction 1 over x squared, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mfrac></math> and the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-axis that lies to the right of the vertical line <math alttext="x equals 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. (a) Find the area of region <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Region <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the base of a solid. For the solid, at each <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> the cross section perpendicular to the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis is a rectangle with area given by <math alttext="x times e raised to the fraction x over 5, power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>x</mi><mo>‚Å¢</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mfrac><mi>x</mi><mn>5</mn></mfrac></msup></mstyle></math>. Find the volume of the solid.

(c) Find the volume of the solid generated when the unbounded region <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>W</mi></math> is revolved about the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-axis.

topic.text: 6.11: (BC ONLY) Integrating Using Integration by Parts

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
